Abstract

In the framework of the Hough transform technique to detect curves in images, we provide a bound for the number of Hough transforms to be considered for a successful optimization of the accumulator function in the recognition algorithm. Such a bound is consequence of geometrical arguments. We also show the robustness of the results when applied to synthetic datasets strongly perturbed by noise. An algebraic approach, discussed in the appendix, leads to a better bound of theoretical interest in the exact case.

Introduction

The Hough transform is a standard technique for feature extraction used in image analysis and digital image processing. Such a technique was first used to detect straight lines in images [9]. It is based on the point-line duality as follows: points on a straight line, defined by an equation in the image plane âŸ¨x,yâŸ©ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\langle x,y\rangle with the usual natural parametrization, correspond to lines in the parameter space âŸ¨A,BâŸ©ğ´ğµ\langle A,B\rangle that intersect in a single point. This point uniquely identifies the coefficients in the equation of the original straight line (analogous procedures to detect circles and ellipses in images have been introduced inÂ [7]). From a computational point of view, this result gives us a procedure to recognize straight lines in 222-dimensional images in which discontinuity regions in the image are highlighted through an edge detection algorithm; the parameter space is discretized in cells and an accumulator function is defined on it, whose maximum provides us with the parametersâ€™ values that identify the line.

Thanks to algebraic geometrical arguments, the Hough transform definition has been extended to include special classes of curves [2, 12]. In [2], a characterization of families of irreducible algebraic plane curves of the same degree for which is defined a Hough-type correspondence is provided. In fact, given a family â„±â„±\mathcal{F} of algebraic curves, a general point pğ‘p in the image plane corresponds to an algebraic locus, Î“pâ€‹(â„±)subscriptÎ“ğ‘â„±\Gamma_{p}(\mathcal{F}), in the parameter space. The families â„±â„±\mathcal{F} such that, as pğ‘p varies on a given curve ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} from â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, satisfy the regularity condition that the hypersurfaces Î“pâ€‹(â„±)subscriptÎ“ğ‘â„±\Gamma_{p}(\mathcal{F}) meet in one and only one point (which in turn defines the curve ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}), are called Hough regular. This paper is a sequel of [2]. Indeed, in [2] the Hough transform technique was performed for the automated recognition of cubic and quartic curves, and the accuracy of the detection was tested against synthetic data. Here, the aim is to reduce the amount of the dataset to be taken into account. Furthermore, the power of this procedure is then tested on 222-dimensional astronomical and medical real images in [12].

Let â„±={ğ’ğ€}â„±subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{F}}=\{{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}}\} be a Hough regular family of algebraic plane curves ğ’ğ€subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}}. Letâ€™s highlight here the steps of the standard recognition algorithm, of a given profile of interest ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}} in a real image, on which the Hough transform technique for such families of plane curves is founded. We refer to [2, Section 6], [12, Section 4], and also [14, Section 5] for complete details.

A pre-processing step of the algorithm consists of the application of a standard edge detection technique on the image (see [6] for a detailed description of this operator). This step reduces the number of points of interest highlighting the profile ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}} of which one has to compute the Hough transform. Then a discretization of the parameter space is required, which possibly exploits bounds on the parameter values computed by using either the Cartesian or the parametric form of the curve in the image space. A last step constructs the accumulator function after a discretization of the parameter space. The value of the accumulator in a cell of the discretized space corresponds to the number of times the Hough transforms of selected points of interest reach that cell. As a final outcome of the algorithm, the parameter values characterizing the curve best approximating the profile ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}} in the image space correspond to the parameter values identifying the cell where the accumulator function reaches its maximum.

Thus, in practice, the computational burden associated to the accumulator function computation and optimization leads to the need of reducing as most as possible the number of points of interest to be considered. By using classical geometrical arguments we provide in Proposition 2.4, and in an exact context, a bound which quite significantly decreases the number of Hough transforms Î“pjâ€‹(â„±)subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±\Gamma_{p_{j}}({\mathcal{F}}) of points pjâˆˆğ’ğ€subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ’ğ€p_{j}\in{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}} making true the regularity condition âˆ©pjÎ“pjâ€‹(â„±)={ğ€}subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±ğ€\cap_{p_{j}}\Gamma_{p_{j}}({\mathcal{F}})=\{\bm{\lambda}\}. This suggests to significantly bound the number of Hough transforms to be considered to recognize curves in images. Indeed, such a bound applies quite efficiently in concrete examples, and it turns out to be quite robust both in presence of noisy background and against random perturbation of pointsâ€™ locations, as shown in Section 4. This significantly enhances the results of [2, Section 6], with special regard to robustness in presence of noisy background.

A better understanding of the behavior of the equations defining the Hough transforms in the parameter space leads to a refinement of Proposition 2.4. This algebraic approach provides a much better bound, called Î½bestsubscriptğœˆbest\nu_{\rm best} (see Proposition A.4, Appendix A), which appears of purely theoretical interest since such a bound can be even too strong for practical purposes. Indeed, let ğ’ğ€subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}} be a curve from a family â„±â„±{\mathcal{F}} potentially approximating a profile ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}}. Since Î½bestsubscriptğœˆbest\nu_{\rm best} can be very small (for instance, Î½best=2subscriptğœˆbest2\nu_{\rm best}=2 in the examples provided in Appendix A), random perturbations of Î½bestsubscriptğœˆbest\nu_{\rm best} pointâ€™s locations on ğ’ğ€subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}} may produce a dataset of points not properly highlighting the profile ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}}.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 1 we recall some background material. Section 2 is devoted to the proof of the bound mentioned above. We then provide several examples in SectionÂ 3. In Section 4, applications to synthetic data for four families of curves (the same considered in [2]) show the efficiency and the robustness of the result. Finally, our conclusions are offered in Section 5.

Given a profile of interest in the image plane, the Hough approach detects a curve from the family â„±â„±\mathcal{F} best approximating the profile by using well-established pattern recognition techniques for the recognition of curves in images (see [2, Sections 6, 7] and also [12, Sections 4, 5]). From a theoretical point of view, the detection procedure can be highlighted as follows.

  1. I.

    Choose a set of points pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}â€™s of interest in the image plane ğ”¸(x,y)2â€‹(â„)superscriptsubscriptğ”¸ğ‘¥ğ‘¦2â„{\mathbb{A}}_{(x,y)}^{2}({\mathbb{R}}).

  2. II.

    In the parameter space ğ”¸ğš²tâ€‹(â„)superscriptsubscriptğ”¸ğš²ğ‘¡â„{\mathbb{A}}_{\bm{\Lambda}}^{t}({\mathbb{R}}) find the intersection of the Hough transforms corresponding to the points pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}â€™s. That is, compute â‹‚jÎ“pjâ€‹(â„±)subscriptğ‘—subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±\bigcap_{j}\Gamma_{p_{j}}(\mathcal{F}) which identifies a (unique) point, ğ€ğ€{\bm{\lambda}}.

  3. III.

    Return the curve ğ’ğ€subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}} uniquely determined by the parameter ğ€ğ€{\bm{\lambda}}.

Because of the presence of noise and approximations (due to the floating point numbers representation encoding the real coordinates) of the points pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}â€™s extracted from a digital image, and consequently on their Hough transforms Î“pjâ€‹(â„±)subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±\Gamma_{p_{j}}({\mathcal{F}}), in practice in most cases it happens that âˆ©jÎ“pjâ€‹(â„±)=âˆ…subscriptğ‘—subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±\cap_{j}\Gamma_{p_{j}}({\mathcal{F}})=\emptyset; though we notice that there are regions in the parameter space with high density of Hough transform crossings. Therefore, from a practical point of view, Step II is usually performed using the so called â€œvoting procedureâ€, a discretization approach that consists of the following three steps.

  • â€¢

    Find a proper discretization of a suitable bounded region ğ’¯ğ’¯{\mathcal{T}} contained in the open set ğ’°âŠ‚â„tğ’°superscriptâ„ğ‘¡{\mathcal{U}}\subset{\mathbb{R}}^{t} of the parameter space.

  • â€¢

    Construct on ğ’¯ğ’¯{\mathcal{T}} an accumulator function, that is, a function that, for each Hough transform Î“pjâ€‹(â„±)subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±\Gamma_{p_{j}}(\mathcal{F}) and for each cell of the discretized region, records and sums the â€œvoteâ€ 111, if Î“pjâ€‹(â„±)subscriptÎ“subscriptğ‘ğ‘—â„±\Gamma_{p_{j}}(\mathcal{F}) crosses the cell, and the â€œvoteâ€ 00 otherwise.

  • â€¢

    Look for the cell associated to the maximum, say ğ¦ğ¦\bf m, of the accumulator function; as suggested by the general results recalled above, the center of that cell is an approximation of the coordinates of the intersection point ğ€ğ¦subscriptğ€ğ¦{\bm{\lambda}}_{\bf m} (see [2, Section 6] and [12, Section 4]). Of course, such an approximation is determined up to the chosen discretization of ğ’¯ğ’¯{\mathcal{T}}.

Furthermore, in practice, Step I is performed by using a finite number of points of interest. Then it is natural to ask, even from a theoretical point of view, how many points pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j} are sufficient to uniquely identify ğ€ğ€\bm{\lambda}.

1.1 Reduction to a finite intersection

Let ğ’ğ€subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}} be a curve from the family â„±={ğ’ğ€}â„±subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{F}}=\{{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}}\}. The natural question this raises is:

In the exact case, minimize the number of points pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}â€™s belonging to a curve ğ’ğ€subscriptğ’ğ€{\mathcal{C}}_{\bm{\lambda}} from the family â„±â„±{\mathcal{F}} such that

3 Examples of interest

In this section we provide the examples we come back on in next Section 4. Such examples belong to classes of curves of interest in astronomical and medical imaging, and widely used in recent literature to best approximate bone profiles and typical solar structures such as coronal loops (for instance, see [2, 12, 13]). These families of curves mainly come from atlas of plane curves as [17], as well as from knowledge of classical tools in algebraic geometry.

We use the notation as in the previous sections. Moreover, for a point p=(xp,yp)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘p=(x_{p},y_{p}) in the image plane ğ”¸(x,y)2â€‹(â„)superscriptsubscriptğ”¸ğ‘¥ğ‘¦2â„{\mathbb{A}}_{(x,y)}^{2}({\mathbb{R}}), we denote by [x0â€‹(p),x1â€‹(p),x2â€‹(p)]subscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘[x_{0}(p),x_{1}(p),x_{2}(p)] its homogeneous coordinates in the real projective plane â„™[x0,x1,x2]2subscriptsuperscriptâ„™2subscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2{\mathbb{P}}^{2}_{[x_{0},x_{1},x_{2}]}.

4 Applications to synthetic data

In this section we show the efficiency of the bound discussed in Section 2 for four families of curves considered in [2]. In particular, we show the robustness of the results when applied to dataset strongly perturbed by noise. We keep the same notation as in [2, Section 6].

From now on, we consider the following set of curves selected from four families: the Descartes Folium of equation (4) with a=3ğ‘3a=3, b=1ğ‘1b=1, the elliptic curve of equation (5) with a=âˆ’4ğ‘4a=-4, b=7ğ‘7b=7, the quartic curve with triple point of equation (6) with a=15ğ‘15a=\frac{1}{5}, b=12ğ‘12b=\frac{1}{2}; and the quartic curve with tacnode of equation (7) with a=1ğ‘1a=1, b=8ğ‘8b=8. These are exactly the same curves considered in [2, Section 6]; from now on, we also refer to them as â€œthe given curvesâ€. As stated in Section II., for a successful recognition of the given curves, we need to find the intersection of the Hough transforms in order to identify ğ€.ğ€{\bm{\lambda}}. The voting procedure requires some steps: first of all, we need to bound the parameter space, selecting minimum and maximum values for the parameters to be considered. In the following we indicate these values with aminsubscriptğ‘mina_{{\rm min}}, amaxsubscriptğ‘maxa_{{\rm max}}, bminsubscriptğ‘minb_{{\rm min}}, and bmaxsubscriptğ‘maxb_{{\rm max}} for Ağ´A and BğµB, respectively. Then, we discretize the region in the parameter space, choosing the cell size Î´asubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{a} along the Ağ´A axis, and the cell size Î´bsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{b} along the BğµB axis. The number of cells along the Ağ´A axis of the parameter space is then computed as:

Na=âŒŠamaxâˆ’aminÎ´aâŒ‹,subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘maxsubscriptğ‘minsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘N_{a}=\lfloor{\frac{a_{{\rm max}}-a_{{\rm min}}}{\delta_{a}}}\rfloor,

and an analogous formula holds for Nb.subscriptğ‘ğ‘N_{b}.

All the values considered in the four cases are collected in Table 1. The parameter spaces are built in such a way that each of them contains a cell corresponding to the pair (a,b)ğ‘ğ‘(a,b) employed to select the curves. In this way, we can achieve an exact recognition, where the error between the original parameters and the recognized ones is equal to zero. Further, it is worth noting that to make the comparison with the results presented in [2] more reliable, in the four cases under consideration we have sampled the same regions of the âŸ¨x,yâŸ©ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\langle x,y\rangle plane and considered the same discretizations of the parameter spaces, as previously done in [2].

4.1 Robustness in absence of noise

We start the analysis testing the bounds given in Proposition 2.4 when no noise is present: for each curve described above we randomly select Î½optsubscriptğœˆopt\nu_{\rm opt} points and apply the recognition algorithm. We repeat the random extraction procedure for 100100100 runs, in order to assess the robustness with respect to the choice of the points in the dataset. For the whole set of curves, we recognize the exact pair of parameters in all the runs. In the first row of Figure 1 we show as an example the curve of the Descartes Folium family with a=3ğ‘3a=3, b=1ğ‘1b=1 (panel (a)), and Î½opt=9subscriptğœˆopt9\nu_{\rm opt}=9 points randomly sampled from it (black circles) (panel (b)); in panel (c) of Figure 1 we present the accumulator function that has a clear peak in the cell corresponding to (a,b)=(3,1)ğ‘ğ‘31(a,b)=(3,1). This cell is selected as the one corresponding to the maximum value of the accumulator and provides us with the parameters of the reconstructed curve (see panel (d)).

4.2 Robustness in presence of noisy background

In this paragraph we present the results concerning the robustness in presence of a very noisy background around the selected curves as above. For each curve we build a database made of N1+N2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2N_{1}+N_{2} points where N1=Î½optsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğœˆoptN_{1}=\nu_{\rm opt} points (dataset points, from now on) satisfy the curve equation, and N2subscriptğ‘2N_{2} points (noise points, from now on) are randomly picked up on the image plane according to a uniform distribution. We test different levels of background noise (99%percent9999\%, 95%percent9595\%, 90%percent9090\%, 85%percent8585\%, 80%percent8080\%), considering

N2Î½opt+N2=x100,subscriptğ‘2subscriptğœˆoptsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘¥100\frac{N_{2}}{\nu_{\rm opt}+N_{2}}=\frac{x}{100}, (8)

where x=99,95,90,85,80ğ‘¥9995908580x=99,95,90,85,80. For the four given curves, the values of N1subscriptğ‘1N_{1} and N2subscriptğ‘2N_{2} and the total number N=N1+N2ğ‘subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2N=N_{1}+N_{2} of Hough transforms, which depends on the background noise level, are summarized in Table 2. Let us remark that the quantity Nğ‘N is definitely lower than the corresponding one employed in [2]. For instance, in the case of background noise at 99%percent9999\% (the only case made explicit in [2]), here we employ 900900900 points for the Descartes Folium and the elliptic curve, 140014001400 for the quartic curve with triple point, and 130013001300 for the quartic curve with tacnode, versus 100001000010000 for the Descartes Folium, 158001580015800 for the elliptic curve, 100001000010000 for the quartic curve with triple point, and 500050005000 for the quartic curve with tacnode as reported in Table 2 of [2].

We repeated the experiments for 100100100 runs, randomly extracting the N1subscriptğ‘1N_{1} points on the curve and the N2subscriptğ‘2N_{2} background noise points. In Table 3 we show the number of runs (out of 100100100) in which the method correctly recognizes the parameters, while in Table 4 we show the average distance and the corresponding standard deviation between the pair of exact parameters and the recognized ones.

In Figure 2 we represent the recognized curves in 100100100 runs when the background noise is at 99%percent9999\%. The colors of the curves are associated to their repetition rates, as follows. Cyan, from 2%percent22\% to 3%percent33\%; green, from 3%percent33\% to 5%percent55\%; yellow, from 5%percent55\% to 10%percent1010\%; orange, from 10%percent1010\% to 20%percent2020\%; red, from 20%percent2020\% to 50%percent5050\%; magenta, higher than 50%percent5050\%. In Figure 3 we show the recognized curves with background noise at 95%percent9595\% level: almost all the recognitions are perfect with the exception of the curve shown in panel (c) where in 3%percent33\% of the cases at most, a profile not perfectly matching the given curve is found. In Figure 4 we show the recognized quartic curve with a triple point when the background noise is decreased to 90%percent9090\% (the only case which seemed critical at the previously considered noise level).

As previously stated, in all the trials the cyan and green curves occurred with a repetition rate lower than 5%percent55\% and for this reason we can assume they are not stable, reliable estimations of the real parameters. Further, as experimentally shown in Tables 3 and 4, the results look stable for background noise starting from 90%percent9090\%, so we omit the tables and figures corresponding to the x=80,85ğ‘¥8085x=80,85 cases.

4.2.1 The case of the Descartes Folium

Tables 3 and 4 show that the recognition of the Descartes Folium is not completely reliable in the case of 99%percent9999\% of background noise points. In [2], the recognition of the Descartes Folium with this background noise percentage was performed by using a total of 100001000010000 points N2=9900subscriptğ‘29900N_{2}=9900 and N1=100subscriptğ‘1100N_{1}=100. Here we want to investigate how much we need to increase the N1subscriptğ‘1N_{1} value (from the initial Î½optsubscriptğœˆopt\nu_{{\rm opt}} value), and consequently the total number of points Nğ‘N, in order to have perfectly reliable recognitions even with 99%percent9999\% of background noise points. We employ the same procedure as in the previous section. In Table 5 we show the number of runs (out of 100100100) in which the method correctly recognizes the parameters of the Descartes Folium for different values of N1subscriptğ‘1N_{1}, and then Nğ‘N. As we can see it is necessary to increase the N1subscriptğ‘1N_{1} value to 252525 in order to have a 100%percent100100\% of correct recognitions in presence of 99%percent9999\% of background noise points.

4.3 Robustness against random perturbation of pointsâ€™ locations

Here we validate the robustness of the recognition method against random perturbations of the location of points on the curves, following the procedure already employed in [2, p. 405], and by using Î½optsubscriptğœˆopt\nu_{\rm opt} instead of N=100ğ‘100N=100. The procedure is repeated for 100100100 runs. More specifically, for each of the four families of curves as above:

  1. 1.

    Take Î½optsubscriptğœˆopt\nu_{\rm opt} points randomly on the curve, according to a uniform distribution.

  2. 2.

    Repeat for 100100100 different runs the steps:

    1. (a)

      perturb each coordinate of each point (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) in this database by means of a Gaussian distribution ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)ğ’©0superscriptğœ2\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) with zero mean and standard deviation Ïƒğœ\sigma;

    2. (b)

      apply the recognition algorithm and determine the pair of parameters characterizing the curve;

    3. (c)

      In the parameter space, compute the Euclidean distance between the computed parameter pair and the exact one.

  3. 3.

    Compute the average value, and corresponding standard deviations, of the 100100100 distances computed in step 222(c).

  4. 4.

    Repeat the procedure from step 222 for a different value of the standard deviation in the Gaussian distribution.

The results of this test are shown in Table 6. First, note that the recognition capability of the method in the case of random perturbations of the pointsâ€™ locations on the curve deteriorates differently for the four curves: the elliptic curve and the quartic curve with tacnode show poor results starting from Ïƒ=0.04ğœ0.04\sigma=0.04, while in the case of the other curves the algorithm performs relatively well even with Ïƒ=0.15ğœ0.15\sigma=0.15. Next, we also look at the number of exact recognitions of the four given curves. The Descartes Folium behaves well for small values of Ïƒğœ\sigma, with exact recognition rates of 24%percent2424\%, 12%percent1212\%, 4%percent44\%, 1%percent11\%, 1%percent11\% for Ïƒ=0.01,0.02,0.04,0.05,0.06ğœ0.010.020.040.050.06\sigma=0.01,~{}0.02,~{}0.04,~{}0.05,~{}0.06, respectively. These values may seem low but, if combined with those shown in TableÂ 6, they indicate that even when not perfect the recognition is still very accurate. The elliptic curve case shows high rates of exact recognition (89%percent8989\%, 44%percent4444\%, 14%percent1414\%, 10%percent1010\%, 4%percent44\%, 1%percent11\% for Ïƒ=0.01,0.02,0.04,0.05,0.06,0.1ğœ0.010.020.040.050.060.1\sigma=0.01,~{}0.02,~{}0.04,~{}0.05,~{}0.06,~{}0.1, respectively), but, at the same time, when the recognition goes wrong, the parameters values we found rather differ from a=âˆ’4ğ‘4a=-4, b=7ğ‘7b=7, also in the case of small values of the standard deviation Ïƒğœ\sigma, thus justifying the overall non-optimal behavior shown in TableÂ 6. In the case of the quartic curve with triple point, we never find the exact parameters a=15ğ‘15a=\frac{1}{5}, b=12ğ‘12b=\frac{1}{2}, but we get parameters values rather close to them for all the considered values of Ïƒğœ\sigma. The quartic curve with tacnode presents an 11%percent1111\% rate of exact recognition for Ïƒ=0.01ğœ0.01\sigma=0.01, while for higher values of Ïƒğœ\sigma the recognition of the exact parameters a=1ğ‘1a=1, b=8ğ‘8b=8 systematically fails.

In Figure 5 we summarize the recognized curves in the 100100100 runs when Ïƒ=0.02ğœ0.02\sigma=0.02 (central column) and Ïƒ=0.04ğœ0.04\sigma=0.04 (right column). The colors of the curves are associated with the repetition rates as above. The repetition rates of the curves are rather low in most of the cases (the cyan color is associated with a repetition rate between the 2%percent22\% and the 3%percent33\%), except for the elliptic curve, in which the given curve associated to a=âˆ’4ğ‘4a=-4, b=7ğ‘7b=7 has a repetition rate from 20%percent2020\% to 50%percent5050\% (red color) for Ïƒ=0.02ğœ0.02\sigma=0.02 and a repetition rate from 10%percent1010\% to 20%percent2020\% (orange color) for Ïƒ=0.04ğœ0.04\sigma=0.04. We note that the quartic curve with tacnode shows a higher average distance between the pair of the exact parameters a=1ğ‘1a=1, b=8ğ‘8b=8 and the pairs of the recognized parameters if compared with the other curves; however, the graphs of the curves associated to the recognized parameters look â€œreasonably closeâ€ to that of the given quartic curve (see Figure 5, last row).

4.4 Computational cost

The use of bound Î½optsubscriptğœˆopt\nu_{\rm{opt}} allows us to recognize the curve by using a relatively small number of â€œgoodâ€ points. Here we assess the reduction of the computational cost when a small set of points is considered: for each family of curves, we measured the time needed to go through the recognition procedure in the case of 99%percent9999\% background noise (the same percentage as in [2]) with the same number of points as in Section 4.2 and in [2]. The results, provided in Table 7, show a significant decrease in terms of time for all the families of curves we considered here with a minimum factor 3.73.73.7 and a maximum 21.221.221.2.

5 Conclusions

We propose a finite bound, Î½optsubscriptğœˆopt\nu_{\rm opt} (see Proposition 2.4), for the number of transforms to be considered in the accumulator function step of the recognition algorithm on which the Hough transform technique is based. Such a bound looks quite reliable and definitely of potential interest to reduce the computational burden associated to the accumulator function computation and optimization. In particular, we obtain quite effective results when the curves are embedded in a noisy background not exceeding 95%percent9595\% (figures 3 and 4). E.g., for background noise at 95%percent9595\%, with a data set of N1=Î½optsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğœˆoptN_{1}=\nu_{\rm opt} and N2=955â€‹Î½opt=19â€‹Î½optsubscriptğ‘2955subscriptğœˆopt19subscriptğœˆoptN_{2}=\frac{95}{5}\nu_{\rm opt}=19\nu_{\rm opt} noise points (see relation (8)), we recognize the curve by considering a total of

N=N1+N2=20â€‹Î½optâ‰ˆ20â€‹d2ğ‘subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘220subscriptğœˆopt20superscriptğ‘‘2N=N_{1}+N_{2}=20\nu_{\rm opt}\approx 20d^{2}

Hough transforms, where dğ‘‘d denotes the degree of the curves from the family. Note that in [2, Section 6, Table I] the recognition is extremely effective even when the curves are embedded in a noisy background at 99%percent9999\%, but using a number Nğ‘N of total Hough transforms which approximately ranges from 5Ã—1035superscript1035\times 10^{3} to 15Ã—10315superscript10315\times 10^{3}.

Not surprisingly, the results are not as good against random perturbations of pointsâ€™ locations on the curves. In the case of the quartic curve with a tacnode (the only one explicitly shown in [2, Table 2]), we may for instance note that by using N1=Î½opt=13subscriptğ‘1subscriptğœˆopt13N_{1}=\nu_{\rm opt}=13 (instead of N1=100subscriptğ‘1100N_{1}=100) we need a standard deviation Ïƒ=0.01ğœ0.01\sigma=0.01 (instead of 0.040.040.04) to get the same average distance and corresponding standard deviation 0.1Â±0.1plus-or-minus0.10.10.1\pm 0.1. Even if our results get worse as Ïƒğœ\sigma increases, they deserve to be noted.
